description:
Bridge protections

This world demonstrates how bridges can offer protection against fatal background tiles but not against fatal obstacles

Artefacts are defined and added in the Onload editor as follows.

INSERT_ONLOAD

Running any program will result in having the code in the Pre editor being executed first.

INSERT_PRE
onload:
# Python code in Onload

# Set Python as the programming language to be
# used elsewhere
RUR.onload_set_programming_language("python")

# Defining a new kind of bridge, protecting
# against fire; note that the protection
# corresponds to the value of the *fatal* attribute
# of the object, and not its name.
# In the case of "fire", both its name
# and its fatal attribute have the same value.

RUR.add_new_thing({"name": "fire_bridge",
   "url": RUR.BASE_URL + "/src/images/daisy.png",
   "protections": ["fire"]
                   })


# Adding "normal" bridge
for x in [3, 4, 5, 6, 7]:
   RUR.add_bridge("bridge", x, 1)

# The usual bridge protects against water 
# and mud as background tiles
RUR.add_background_tile("water", 3, 1)
RUR.add_background_tile("mud", 4, 1)

# But bridges cannot protect against obstacles
RUR.add_obstacle("water", 5, 1)
RUR.add_obstacle("mud", 6, 1)

# Note that bridges are drawn on top of
# background tiles, but below obstacles

# The normal bridge cannot protect against fire
# even as background tiles
RUR.add_background_tile("fire", 7, 1)

# Add more fire but a different bridge
RUR.add_background_tile("fire", 9, 1)
RUR.add_bridge("fire_bridge", 9, 1)
